dt: {bc}to go or move stealthily or furtively (as in fear or shame) {bc}{sx|steal||}
{bc}to move in a sinuous provocative manner
used especially of a domestic animal

pt: {sc}lurk{/sc} {sc}skulk{/sc} {sc}slink{/sc} {sc}sneak{/sc} mean to behave so as to escape attention. {sc}lurk{/sc} implies a lying in wait in a place of concealment and often suggests an evil intent.
{sc}skulk{/sc} suggests more strongly cowardice or fear or sinister intent.
{sc}slink{/sc} implies moving stealthily often merely to escape attention.
{sc}sneak{/sc} may add an implication of entering or leaving a place or evading a difficulty by furtive or underhanded methods.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}slincan{/it} to creep; akin to Old English {it}slingan{/it} to worm, twist
shortdef: to go or move stealthily or furtively (as in fear or shame) : steal
to move in a sinuous provocative manner
to give premature birth to —used especially of a domestic animal

dt: {bc}the young of an animal (such as a calf) brought forth prematurely
{bc}the flesh or skin of such an animal

shortdef: the young of an animal (such as a calf) brought forth prematurely; also : the flesh or skin of such an animal
